title: Success?
text: What would we consider as a "success" in 1 trial of this situation? By the way the situation is presented, it is fairly clear that the dolphin doing the trick should be considered a win. This is because the probability of our dolphin doing a trick was brought up before the probability of our dolphin failing. In addition, this means that a "failure" would be the dolphin failing the trick.

title: Binomial Equations
text: Keep in mind that the equation to calculate binomial probabilities is: (n choose x) * $$p^x$$ * $$q^{n-x}$$, where n $$=$$ total trials, x $$=$$ trials with a success, p $$=$$ probabilty of success, and q $$=$$ probability of failure. You can also use most calculators nowadays to calculate binomial probabilities, in addition to the internet.

title: Variables
text: Now that we have our equation, what will all our relevant variables be? n $$=$$ 5, x $$=$$ 2, p $$=$$ .65, and q $$=$$ .35.
